subscription.translation[0].definitions[: an amount of money you pay, usually once a year, to receive copies of a newspaper or magazine, or receive a service, or the act of paying money for this
You may cancel your subscription at any time.
I’ve decided not to renew my subscription.
Are you interested in taking out a subscription to ‘Newsweek’  (=arranging to buy it on a regular basis)?
an amount of money you pay regularly to be a member of an organization or to help its work, or the act of paying money for this
when people in a country or place give money in order to pay for something to be done
The church’s 120-foot Gothic spire was paid for by public subscription in 1939.
An annual subscription to the magazine costs $20.
She took out a subscription to the Scientific American.
Please give a month's notice if you are cancelling your subscription.
It’s time to renew your subscription.
We pay a monthly subscription for the sports channel.
If you pay a subscription fee, you can watch matches on the Internet.
subscription.translation[1].definitions[: an amount of money you pay regularly to receive a newspaper, magazine, or broadcasting or telephone service
A subscription to their quarterly report costs $575 a year.
The World Service TV channel is a subscription service available to millions of homes around the world.
when a company offers shares to the public
They intend to raise £1.9 million via a share subscription.
The subscription price for the new shares was 225p.
the act of asking to buy or agreeing to buy shares in a company
25.2 million shares are available for subscription.
Existing shareholders have priority subscription rights (=the right to subscribe to shares before they are offered to anyone else).
an amount of money that you pay regularly to be a member of an organization or to help it
his subscription for the Student Union
